snippet: A retired police sergeant put five years and $100,000 into making his own model of the beloved film car, which was to make its public debut Friday at the New York International Auto Show in Manhattan.
abstract: New York International Auto Show will feature intricate replica of car from classic film Chitty Chitty Bang Bang; project was labor of love by retired New York City Police Sgt Tony Garofalo, who spent five years and more than $100,000 completing restoration of 1914 coupe he found in New Jersey junkyard.
lead_paragraph: A retired police sergeant put five years and $100,000 into making his own model of the beloved film car, which was to make its public debut Friday at the New York International Auto Show in Manhattan.

headline.main: Sgt. Pepper Builds a Real-Life Chitty Chitty Bang Bang on Long Island
headline.print_headline: A Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, Built by Sergeant Pepper
